posts.name: Rijoy Sarkar
posts.cooked: Our team has been using an 8 Falcon mk4 drivetrain with an L2 ratio. We have had a pretty good experience so far, but with the probable discontinuation of Falcons and the added capability of the Kraken motor, we are considering switching to using Krakes as our drive motor. That said, from the information gathered so far, we would need to purchase 3-4 additional Kraken motors and 4 pinion sets for approximately $700-$900. We do have some spare Falcons on hand, so a motor failure isn’t a major concern right now—we’re mostly looking to enhance our drivetrain. Is this upgrade worth the investment? Are there any other components we’d need to acquire? Additionally, what are some other ways we can improve our drivetrain?

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked:
Kraken robots offer slightly more power and efficiency at higher currents compared to others. However, overall performance differences might not significantly impact gameplay unless your team excels. Instead of focusing on drivetrain performance, I’d prioritize building a dependable robot and enhancing its speed mechanisms. If you’re encountering reliability issues linked to Falcons, switching could indeed be a more critical step than considering power levels.

Though Kraken robots shouldn’t cause harm (I was satisfied with them this year), you can allocate remaining Falcons to working on mechanisms instead.

Budgeting considerations include purchasing torque wrenches from either CTRE or WCP, as these tools are essential to prevent motor damage from over-torquing terminals.

The most significant improvement in your drivetrain likely comes from programming and driver practice. Analyzing top-performing teams’ code for swerve drive simplicity could provide valuable insights.

Additionally, tracking time spent driving versus other tasks—like alignment or placement—could help optimize your approach. For instance, reviewing WildStang Robotics' build blog for practical insights into improving your robot’s efficiency.

link_counts.title: WildStang Robotics Program: Team 111 and 112 Build Blog - 2025

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: I don’t think there will be that much of a boost in performance from switching. I’d recommend experimenting with different gear ratios and improving both software and drive practice. I’d still suggest obtaining kraken(s) because they are highly effective and versatile across various systems, though they may not result in significant changes.

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked: We are currently using falcons for steer and Kraken for drive. Since the falcons are NLA, we will eventually convert to all Kraken. There isn't a cost advantage aside from having the falcons already.

posts.name: Rijoy Sarkar
posts.cooked:
Here’s the cleaned-up version of your text:

We already possess four Kraken robots, though we're currently employing them for mechanism-based tasks. We originally stated we'd purchase around three, but anything extra could potentially be utilized for falcon-related purposes. This year, we noticed our drivetrain was relatively slow, and I’m not entirely sure why—it’s my first year participating in the FIRST Robotics Competition. As for the best swerve code among teams, I’d need to look into that further. Additionally, we plan to rebuild our swerve modules for maintenance, addressing several issues we’ve identified during testing.

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked:
The teams whose code I examine closely include 254, 1678, 6328, and 2910. While copying code isn't wrong, it's essential to invest time in understanding it deeply, as it often contains complexities suitable for less experienced teams. Unfortunately, I don't have a strong suggestion for simpler code.

- Limiting your drivetrain's acceleration improves control.
- A "slow mode" with reduced max velocity and acceleration offers finer control.
- Buttons let you snap the robot to specific angles, such as those near coral stations.

When reviewing matches, the robot seems adequately fast; it appears the driver needs more practice, resulting in jerky movements.

posts.name: Rijoy Sarkar
posts.cooked: We do have a slow mode and set positions to snap the robot to preset areas. We could’ve optimized the center of gravity better to reduce the bot’s jerking movements. We plan to prioritize driver practice more heavily. My opinion is that being slower makes sense since my graduating lead programmer suggested moving toward faster autonomous capabilities. While I’m not entirely sure about the accuracy of this statement or if I misunderstood its context, based on this information, I don’t believe Kraken Swerve is worth the increased cost, so we’ll likely focus on software improvements and driver training. Thank you!

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked: I think it depends on how old your falcon 500 motors are. In 2023, we used a full falcon 500 swerve for the entire year and competed once in isr #2 in 2024. Over time, we noticed more problems with the motors. Before isr #4, we upgraded the drive motor to Kraken, seeing only a small improvement in performance. This year, we again used Kraken as the steering motor because our falcon 500s were getting old and we couldn't test other motors like the neo.

posts.name: Trevor Dayal (he/him)
posts.cooked:
It is also game specific. Games utilizing full-field cycling (2023, 2024) prioritize higher maximum speeds, necessitating lower gear ratios alongside powerful motors. Conversely, in half-field or quarter-field games (2019, 2025), enhanced acceleration and mechanism speed become crucial, suggesting falcon designs with optimized gear ratios may perform better.

Additionally, you can explore drivetrain configurations on recalc, which will aid in refining your decision-making process.

Moreover, a notable discussion on recalc论坛 highlighted important aspects related to current limitations, indicating that the 3005 design effectively balances performance across various conditions, with many competitors also favoring Neos.

link_counts.title: PSA: Your Motor Curves Are Wrong (A Whitepaper About Current Limits)

posts.name: Rahul Yarlagadda
posts.cooked: What are you using for steering encoders and a gyro? If all your electronics are from CTRE, you can generate swerve drivetrain code using TunerX. This swerve code is more or less what many top teams are using.
